title: Richard Hönigswald
text:
Richard Hönigswald (18 July 1875 in <a href="Magyar-%C3%93v%C3%A1r">Magyar-Óvár</a> in the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> (the present <a href="Mosonmagyar%C3%B3v%C3%A1r">Mosonmagyaróvár</a> in <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>) – 11 June 1947 in <a href="New%20Haven%2C%20Connecticut">New Haven, Connecticut</a>) was a well-known <a href="philosopher">philosopher</a> belonging to the wider circle of <a href="neo-Kantianism">neo-Kantianism</a>.
Biography.
Hönigswald studied <a href="medicine">medicine</a> and <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a> under <a href="Alois%20Riehl">Alois Riehl</a> and <a href="Alexius%20von%20Meinong">Alexius von Meinong</a> and from 1916 was professor of philosophy, <a href="psychology">psychology</a> and <a href="pedagogy">pedagogy</a> in <a href="Breslau">Breslau</a> (now <a href="Wroc%C5%82aw">Wrocław</a>). There he supervised <a href="Norbert%20Elias">Norbert Elias</a>'s doctorate up to its conclusion in 1924. He also influenced <a href="Hans-Georg%20Gadamer">Hans-Georg Gadamer</a> towards philosophy after the latter attended a seminar Hönigswald conducted on the philosophy of language. From 1930 he was a professor at <a href="Munich">Munich</a>. The emphasis of his work lay on the <a href="cognitive%20psychology">theory of cognition</a> from the point of view of validation and the <a href="philosophy%20of%20language">philosophy of language</a>. Beyond that, Hönigswald tried to develop a method of teaching that would be applicable to the <a href="natural%20sciences">natural sciences</a> and the <a href="humanities">humanities</a> equally. He also dealt with questions of the psychology of <a href="thought">thought</a> and of pedagogy.
In 1933, as a Jew, he was compulsorily retired after the Law for the Restoration of Professional Civil Service was passed in Germany. At the time of the <a href="Kristallnacht">Kristallnacht</a> ("The Night of Broken Glass") in 1938, he spent three weeks in <a href="Dachau%20concentration%20camp">Dachau concentration camp</a>. In 1939 he emigrated with his wife and daughter by way of <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
The discovery of the collection of Hönigswald's unpublished writings led to the so-called third phase of Neo-Kantianism after the phases launched by <a href="Hermann%20Cohen">Hermann Cohen</a> and <a href="Paul%20Natorp">Paul Natorp</a> (<a href="epistemological">epistemological</a> phase) and <a href="Heinrich%20Rickert">Heinrich Rickert</a>, <a href="Wilhelm%20Windelband">Wilhelm Windelband</a>, and <a href="Emil%20Lask">Emil Lask</a> (<a href="ontological">ontological</a>-theoretical phase), respectively.
